quotes.speaker: Hamilton Helmer
quotes.text: The answer to your question is when should you be thinking about this? The answer is always. Even before you have product-market fit, it's worth thinking about strategy. Not strategy in the sense of this fully articulated strategic planning. At the earlier stage, the questions are of the business propositions that you're thinking of, what are the underlying characteristics that might tilt them towards the availability of power or not?

quotes.speaker: Hamilton Helmer
quotes.text: Another thing that's quite surprising about iconic businesses is they often have a second act or a third act or fourth act. Think of AWS or Intel going into CPUs or Apple going into iPhones, all not the origin of business. And that's actually common, not unusual, and that's starting the process all over again.

quotes.speaker: Hamilton Helmer
quotes.text: Power is those economic structures that provide durability of return, a refuge from the withering arbitrage of everybody who wants to eat your lunch. There's something in what you do that gives you either a cost or price advantage over others. And the barrier side is that there's something durable about that, that competitors can't take away from you. Benefit and a barrier, we call it the to be or not to be test.

quotes.speaker: Hamilton Helmer
quotes.text: Almost every startup starts with counter positioning because remember what product market fit is primarily is a substitution. You are coming up with a way to satisfy a more or less existing need in a novel way that creates more value. If you don't have counter positioning at that point you're pretty high risk from an incumbent who already has the capabilities necessary to do that.

quotes.speaker: Hamilton Helmer
quotes.text: We laugh whenever we hear somebody say they have a flywheel, which gives you the idea of network economies. There are often flywheels, the ones that really are material, are rare. The key thing here is materiality, not whether the flywheel exists, but whether the effect is strong enough to really tilt returns.

quotes.speaker: Hamilton Helmer
quotes.text: For me the difference is materiality, whether the value benefit is large enough to engender a price delta significant enough to give you materially different margins into the future. There are lots of things that I would say have network effects but not network economies.

quotes.speaker: Hamilton Helmer
quotes.text: One of the tricks to understanding power is you have to have a pretty good understanding of why it's a castle and not a shack. Netflix spent enormous resources on their UI, recommendation engine, interface with the content world. Those things are important, but they can largely be mimicked. When Blockbuster finally did a DVD business, you couldn't tell their UI site different from Netflix. They just copied it.

quotes.speaker: Hamilton Helmer
quotes.text: If you think of strategy not statically as endpoints, but if you look at dynamically how you get there, operational excellence is essential for strategy. Those things like Netflix's UI and recommendation engine were critical in attaining competitive position. But in themselves, they're not sources of power typically unless they're material and opaque, some way people can't easily imitate them.

quotes.speaker: Hamilton Helmer
quotes.text: If you're in a stability phase of business, you're stuck with this funny thing: most of your day is on operational issues and it should be, because if you don't do it a competitor can and they end up better than you. You're on a treadmill. If you stop running that treadmill, you get creamed. So you got to do it, it's most of your day, but it's not power.

quotes.speaker: Hamilton Helmer
quotes.text: Generative AI's biggest impact will be that tertiary class: used in a lot of things that existed before and exist after but are made better by it, like semiconductors and automobiles. It reminds me of electricity. When electricity came you could completely reconfigure a factory floor. But that took a lot of redesign, incorporation, investment, learning, complements. I tend to think AI will be more like that.

quotes.speaker: Hamilton Helmer
quotes.text: Action is the first principle of business. You do stuff and my book is very oriented towards that. The idea was not to tell you what to do, but to give you guideposts while you're on that journey. I encourage you to do stuff. That's where it all starts and I can think about it and maybe help a little bit, but it's mostly doing stuff.

takeaways: Strategy should be considered from day one, not just after product-market fit. Even at the earliest stages, founders should evaluate which business propositions tilt toward the availability of power, not just customer demand.

Most startups begin with counter positioning as their first source of power, because product-market fit is primarily a substitution against incumbents who could otherwise easily extend their capabilities to compete.

Having a flywheel or network effects does not mean you have power. The key test is materiality: whether the effect is strong enough to create meaningfully different margins into the future, not just whether the flywheel exists.

Operational excellence is essential for attaining competitive position but is almost never a durable source of power. Most operational advantages can be mimicked by hiring the right people or consultants, putting you on a treadmill you must run but that does not protect you.

Action is the first principle of business. Strategy frameworks are guideposts, not blueprints. Iconic businesses often achieve greatness through second and third acts that could not have been planned from the start.

contrarian_candidates.why: Directly challenges the ubiquitous flywheel narrative in tech - most flywheels lack the materiality to constitute actual power
Operational excellence is a treadmill, not a moat - contradicts the common belief that execution speed and excellence create lasting defensibility
Even the most thoughtful product work (UI, recommendations) can be completely copied - challenges the builder culture that equates craft with defensibility
